sectionTitle: Jainism in Action: A Guide to Health, Nutrition, and Yoga

tabs.caption: Explore the fundamental connections between Jain philosophy, physical health, and spiritual well-being.

tabData.title: The Jain Approach to Holistic Well-being

items.header: Spirituality and Health: The Intrinsic Link
items.content: Jain principles emphasize that spiritual health and physical health are deeply interconnected. Research shows that spiritual practices like meditation can lead to better health outcomes, including faster recovery and greater happiness. Conversely, good physical health, maintained through proper nutrition and exercise, is crucial for fostering a healthy mind, which is essential for spiritual progress.

A cornerstone of Jain practice is a well-balanced, cruelty-free, and vegan diet. This diet not only aligns with the principle of Ahimsa (non-violence) but also promotes physical health. It focuses on plant-based foods that provide all essential nutrients without causing harm to other living beings.

Soy protein is highlighted as a superior alternative to animal-based proteins because it contains all the essential amino acids for human nutrition. The USDA recognizes that a daily intake of 25 grams of soy protein, as part of a diet low in saturated fat and cholesterol, may significantly reduce the risk of heart disease.

A 'Jain-friendly' diet involves careful selection of ingredients. It strictly excludes animal products like gelatin, certain broths, and eggs. As an added austerity and to practice a higher level of non-violence, many Jains also avoid root vegetables (like potatoes, onions, and garlic) because harvesting them can harm countless microorganisms in the soil.

items.header: Yoga: Exercise for Body and Soul
items.content: Physical exercise, particularly Yoga, is presented as a vital component of a healthy lifestyle. The practice of various Āsans (postures) not only strengthens the body but also enhances mental conditioning, improves concentration, and prepares the individual for deeper meditation and introspection, thereby aiding spiritual growth.

tabs.caption: A step-by-step guide to various yoga postures (Āsans) and their profound benefits for the body and mind.

tabData.title: A Guide to Jain Yoga Postures (Āsans)

items.content:
Purpose

To strengthen eye muscles, prevent eyestrain, and improve eyesight.

Steps

  • Rolling: Without moving your head, look up/down, right/left, diagonally, and in circles (clockwise/anti-clockwise). Repeat 5 times.
  • Focusing: Hold a thumb a foot from your face, focus on it, then on a distant object, then back. Repeat 5 times.
  • Palming: Rub palms together until warm, then cup them gently over closed eyes to soothe and relax them.

Steps

  1. Stand erect, feet together.
  2. Inhale (2s), raising arms and heels simultaneously. Stretch arms up, palms inward.
  3. Hold the maximum stretch, retaining breath for 4 seconds.
  4. Exhale (2s), bringing arms and heels down. Repeat.

Benefits

  • Stretches the entire body and spine vertically.
  • Improves lung capacity and blood circulation.
  • Strengthens abdominal muscles and improves neuro-muscular coordination.

Steps

  1. Stand with feet 3-4 feet apart. Point right foot out.
  2. Stretch arms to shoulder level. Bring left arm straight up. Inhale.
  3. Exhale, bend to the right, sliding the right hand down the leg.
  4. Look up at the left hand. Hold and breathe before repeating on the other side.

Benefits

  • Stretches and develops spinal muscles.
  • Tones foot and ankle muscles; makes hips and thighs more elastic.
  • Stimulates lumbar nerves and improves breathing and balance.

Steps

  1. Sit with legs stretched out.
  2. Fold the right leg, placing the foot on the opposite thigh.
  3. Fold the left leg, placing it on the opposite thigh. Knees should touch the mat.
  4. Keep spine erect, chest open. Rest hands on heels, palms up.
  5. Hold for 10 minutes with normal breathing.

Benefits

  • Considered the best meditative posture.
  • Tones thighs and increases lower body flexibility.
  • Cures joint pains (ankles, knees) and relieves constipation.
  • Relaxes the mind, increases concentration, and reduces tension.

Steps

  1. Sit kneeling, with heels apart and buttocks resting in the cavity between them.
  2. Keep thighs together, spine erect. Rest hands on thighs.
  3. Close eyes, breathe normally, and reflect on the previous day's events.
  4. Hold for 10 minutes.

Benefits

  • Corrects posture and improves ankle/foot flexibility.
  • Strengthens leg and thigh muscles.
  • Aids mental conditioning and emotional control. Excellent preparation for meditation.
  • Develops awareness and aids introspection.

Steps

  1. Begin in Vajrāsan (Thunderbolt Pose).
  2. Holding your toes, lean back and lower your elbows to the floor.
  3. Lower your entire body to the floor, retaining the leg position.
  4. Hold for one minute, then return to Vajrāsan.

Benefits

  • Stretches ligaments and tendons, maintaining their elasticity.
  • Provides an outstanding effect on blood circulation.
  • Staying in the pose for 10-15 minutes can diminish pain in the feet.

Steps

  1. Begin in Vajrāsan (Thunderbolt Pose).
  2. Inhale and raise your hands over your head.
  3. Exhale, bend forward, touching your hands and forehead to the floor.
  4. Hold for one minute, then return to Vajrāsan.

Benefits

  • Reduces high blood pressure.
  • Calms anger and helps maintain a state of peace.
  • Strengthens the muscles of the legs, thighs, and spine.

Steps

  1. Lie on your stomach, chin on the ground, hands by chest with palms down.
  2. Inhale slowly, raising the head, trunk, and abdomen until the navel.
  3. Lift only the upper body, like a cobra's head.
  4. Hold the breath in the raised position.
  5. Exhale slowly and return to the starting position.

Benefits

  • Keeps the dorsal spine elastic and flexible.
  • Reduces pain in the ribs and spinal cord.
  • Stretches abdominal muscles, relieving constipation and intestinal gas.
  • Eliminates feelings of uncertainty and inferiority.

Steps

  1. Lie on your stomach. Inhale and bend knees up.
  2. Reach back and clasp your ankles. Exhale.
  3. Inhale, raising your head and chest while pulling ankles up, lifting thighs off the floor to create an arch.
  4. Hold for three deep breaths, then exhale and release.

Benefits

  • Prevents premature calcification of vertebral joints.
  • Strengthens ligaments, muscles, and nerves along the spine.
  • Improves blood flow to the digestive system and reduces anxiety.
